change.item: Encoded in EAD by Justin Holzer
Liam Sperrazza arranged and described the 2019 accession

repository.corpname: M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections & Archives

did.abstract: The Department of History Records contains documents related to the Bachelor of Arts degree, a Doctor of Philosophy degree, a Masters of Arts Degree, and a Certificate of Advanced Study in Public History. Documents also relate to the changing thematic and geographic focus of various degree tracks.
did.physloc: The materials are located onsite in the department.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Existing collection arranged by Ben Covell in 2015. Additional accession processed by Gregory Wiedeman in 2019. The collection was processed again by Liam Sperrazza in 2025.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Faculty meeting minutes are restricted due to the presence of personnel information and access must be permitted by the University Archivist and the Department of History. The other portions of the collection are open for use.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: All items in this collection were transfered to the University Libraries, M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives. The collection began with a transfer from former faculty member Harry S. Price. This includes the subject files and memoranda and the pre-1990 meeting minutes. Price's personal records were split off into the Harry Price Papers. An additional accession in 2019 transfered the syllabi and post-1990 minutes.

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: This collection contains material that relates to the establishment and/or retrenchment of the PhD Program, various social studies degrees and the Public History Program. The Doctoral Program in History was established in 1965 with the rapid expansion of the school into a research university, but was de-certified in 1975 in the wake of widespread cuts. The program was reintroduced in 1992.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Department of History Records contain correspondence, memorandums, and meeting minutes related to administrative operations. Items also include course descriptions, resource directories, and programs of various events. Interdepartmental programs with Library Science, Social Studies, and Liberal Arts are also documented. This collection also contains a Nobel Prize Nomination that was developed by a faculty member of the History Department.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into 4 series. Series 1 and 3 arranged chronologically and series 2 and 4 arranged alphabetically.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

Identification of specific item, series, box, folder, Department of History Records, 1962-2018. M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives, University Libraries, University at Albany, State University of New York (hereafter referred to as the Department of History Records).

controlaccess.subject: Academic disciplines
UAlbany Academic Departments
controlaccess.corpname: State University of New York at Albany

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains departmental communications, documenting social events, guidance and opportunities for students, department news, enrollment numbers, class lists, interview schedules, and annoucements of faculty appointments.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to faculty meeting minuntes are restricted do to the presence of personnel information. Access to certain minutes must be approved by both the University Archives and the Department of History.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Faculty minutes document both department policies and procedures as well as routine activities. The minutes commonly discuss course proposals, faculty appointments, general education requirements, tenure reviews, and procedures for discretionary salary increases.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains syllabi used for undergraduate and graduate history courses, which show an outline of the course schedule, readings, assignments, and course policies such as plagarism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains publications, guides, forms and summaries from the University and the College of Arts & Sciences, programs for commencement and other events, correspondence, self-evaluations, department planning, alumni newsletters, course descriptions and proposal, department and affiliated department undergraduate and graduate academic program development handouts, and the materials provided for the nomination of Raoul Wallenberg for the 1982 Nobel Prize.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Web crawling is managed through the Internet Archive's Archive-It service. This page includes links to both the university's collection and the Internet Archive's public collection.

Surface-level crawling of www.albany.edu is performed daily which should includes most top-level webpages. Separate targeted crawls of every albany.edu subdomain are performed monthly to attempt to gather all content. This includes: www.albany.edu, www.rna.albany.edu, www.ctg.albany.edu, www.ualbanysports.com, www.albany.edu/rockefeller, www.albany.edu/cela, www.albany.edu/asrc, m.albany.edu, library.albany.edu, events.albany.edu, cstar.cestm.albany.edu, csda.albany.edu, and alumni.albany.edu

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The departmental website was used for promoting the department's programs to potential students and for news and reference information for current students and faculty.

did.unittitle: WARC file for http://www.albany.edu/history/, (please see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_ARChive for more details)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: WARC files are very large and difficult to work with. Your request may take time to process, and we may be unable to deliver your request remotely. Please consult an archivist if you are interested in researching with web archives.
